ch.lambdaj
Class Lambda

java.lang.Object
  ch.lambdaj.Lambda

public final class Lambda
extends java.lang.Object

This class consists exclusively of static methods that allow to use all the core features of the lambdaj library.

Author:
Mario Fusco, Luca Marrocco

          Returns a lambda function defined as:

aggregateFrom : (aggregator, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object to be aggregated.

Method Detail

on

public static <T> T on(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
Constructs a proxy object that mocks the given Class registering all the subsequent invocations on the object.

Parameters:
clazz - The class of the object to be mocked
Returns:
An object of the given class that register all the invocations made on it

forEach

public static <T> T forEach(java.lang.Iterable<? extends T> iterable)
Transforms a collection of Ts in a single object having the same methods of a single instance of T. That allows to invoke a method on each T in the collection with a single strong typed method call as in the following example:

List personInFamily = asList(new Person("Domenico"), new Person("Mario"), new Person("Irma")); forEach(personInFamily).setLastName("Fusco");

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the items in the iterable
Parameters:
iterable - The iterable to be transformed
Returns:
An object that proxies all the item in the iterable or null if the iterable is null or empty
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is null or empty

forEach

public static <T> T forEach(java.lang.Iterable<? extends T> iterable,
                            java.lang.Class<?> clazz)
Transforms a collection of Ts in a single object having the same methods of a single instance of T. That allows to invoke a method on each T in the collection with a single strong typed method call as in the following example:

List personInFamily = asList(new Person("Domenico"), new Person("Mario"), new Person("Irma")); forEach(personInFamily, Person.class).setLastName("Fusco");

The given class represents the proxied by the returned object, so it should be a superclass of all the objects in the iterable. This overloaded version should be always used when it is not insured that the given iterable is null or empty.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the items in the iterable
Parameters:
iterable - The iterable to be transformed
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
Returns:
An object that proxies all the item in the iterable. If the given iterable is null or empty it returns an instance of T that actually proxies an empty Iterable of Ts

collect

public static <T> java.util.List<? extends T> collect(java.lang.Object iterable)
Collects the items in the given iterable putting them in a List. Actually it treats also Maps as Iterables by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of which the items should be collected
Returns:
A List containing all the items collected from the give iterable
Throws:
A - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is not an Iterable or a Map

collect

public static <T> java.util.List<T> collect(java.lang.Object iterable,
                                            T argument)
For each item in the given iterable collects the value defined by the given argument and put them in a List. For example the following code:

List myFriends = asList(new Person("Biagio", 39), new Person("Luca", 29), new Person("Celestino", 29)); List ages = collect(meAndMyFriends, on(Person.class).getAge());

extracts the ages of all the Persons in the list and put them in a List of Integer.

Actually it treats also Maps as Iterables by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of which the items should be collected
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A List containing all the items collected from the give iterable
Throws:
A - RuntimeException if the iterable is not an Iterable or a Map

filter

public static <T> java.util.List<T> filter(org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher,
                                           java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable)
Filters all the objects in the given iterable that match the given hamcrest Matcher

Parameters:

matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given iterable
Returns:
A sublist of the given iterable containing all the objects that match the given hamcrest Matcher

comparator - The comparator used to decide if 2 items are different or not

aggregate

public static <T> T aggregate(java.lang.Object iterable,
                              Aggregator<T> aggregator)
Aggregates the items in the given iterable using the given Aggregator. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of numbers to be summed
aggregator - The function that defines how the objects in this iterable have to be aggregated
Returns:
The result of the aggregation of all the items in the given iterable
Throws:
A - RuntimeException if the iterable is not an Iterable

aggregate

public static <T> T aggregate(java.lang.Object iterable,
                              Aggregator<T> aggregator,
                              java.lang.Object argument)
For each item in the given iterable collects the value defined by the given argument and then aggregates them iterable using the given Aggregator. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of numbers to be summed
aggregator - The function that defines how the objects in this iterable have to be aggregated
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
The result of the aggregation of all the items in the given iterable
Throws:
A - RuntimeException if the iterable is not an Iterable

aggregateFrom

public static <T,A> T aggregateFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable,
                                    Aggregator<A> aggregator)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

aggregateFrom : (aggregator, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object to be aggregated. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be aggregated.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be aggregated.
aggregator - The function that defines how the objects in this iterable have to be aggregated
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing an aggregation lambda function
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is null or empty

aggregateFrom

public static <T,A> T aggregateFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable,
                                    java.lang.Class<?> clazz,
                                    Aggregator<A> aggregator)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

aggregateFrom : (aggregator, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object to be aggregated. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be aggregated. This overloaded version should be always used when it is not insured that the given iterable is null or empty.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be aggregated.
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
aggregator - The function that defines how the objects in this iterable have to be aggregated
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing an aggregation lambda function

sum

public static java.lang.Number sum(java.lang.Object iterable)
Sums the items in the given iterable of Numbers or the iterable itself if it actually is already a single number. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of numbers to be summed
Returns:
The sum of all the Number in the given iterable or the iterable itself if it actually is already a single number
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is not neither an Iterable nor a Number

sum

public static <T> T sum(java.lang.Object iterable,
                        T argument)
Sums the property values of the items in the given iterable defined by the given argument. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of items containing the property of which the values have to be summed.
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
The sum of the property values extracted from all the items in the given iterable
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is not an Iterable

sumFrom

public static <T> T sumFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

sumFrom : (+, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => number) => number

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a number. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be summed as in the following example

int totalAge = sumFrom(persons).getAge();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be summed.
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a sum lambda function
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is null or empty

sumFrom

public static <T> T sumFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable,
                            java.lang.Class<?> clazz)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

sumFrom : (+, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => number) => number

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a number. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be summed as in the following example

int totalAge = sumFrom(persons, Person.class).getAge();

This overloaded version should be always used when it is not insured that the given iterable is null or empty.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be summed.
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a sum lambda function

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of numbers to be summed
Returns:
The minimum of all the Object in the given iterable
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is not an Iterable

min

public static <T> T min(java.lang.Object iterable,
                        T argument)
Finds the minimum item in the given iterable defined by the given argument. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects on which the minimum should be found
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
The minimum of all the Object in the given iterable
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is not an Iterable

minFrom

public static <T> T minFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

minFrom : (min, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object of which a minimum value needs to be found. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be aggregated.

int minAge = maxFrom(persons).getAge();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects on which the minimum should be found
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a min lambda function
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is null or empty

minFrom

public static <T> T minFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable,
                            java.lang.Class<?> clazz)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

minFrom : (min, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object of which a minimum value needs to be found. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be aggregated.

int minAge = minFrom(persons).getAge();

This overloaded version should be always used when it is not insured that the given iterable is null or empty.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects containing the property of which the minimum should be found.
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a min lambda function

joinFrom

public static <T> T joinFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

joinFrom : (concat, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => string

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a String. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be summed as in the following example

String names = joinFrom(persons).getFirstName();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be joined.
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a join lambda function
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is null or empty

joinFrom

public static <T> T joinFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable,
                             java.lang.String separator)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

joinFrom : (concat, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => string

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a String. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be summed as in the following example

String names = joinFrom(persons, " - ").getFirstName();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be joined.
separator - The String used to separe the Strings produced by this lambda function
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a join lambda function
Throws:
An - IllegalArgumentException if the iterable is null or empty

joinFrom

public static <T> T joinFrom(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable,
                             java.lang.Class<?> clazz)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

joinFrom : (concat, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => string

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a String. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be summed as in the following example

String names = joinFrom(persons, Person.class).getFirstName();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method. This overloaded version should be always used when it is not insured that the given iterable is null or empty.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be joined.
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a join lambda function

join

public static java.lang.String join(java.lang.Object iterable)
Joins all the object in the given iterable by concatenating all their String representation. It invokes toString() an all the objects and concatening them using the default separator ", ". Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be joined
Returns:
The concatenation of the String representation of all the objects in the given iterable or an empty String if the iterable is null or empty

join

public static java.lang.String join(java.lang.Object iterable,
                                    java.lang.String separator)
Joins all the object in the given iterable by concatenating all their String representation. It invokes toString() an all the objects and concatening them using the given separator. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be joined
separator - The String used to separe the item's String representation
Returns:
The concatenation of the String representation of all the objects in the given iterable or an empty String if the iterable is null or empty

convert

public static <F,T> java.util.List<T> convert(java.lang.Object iterable,
                                              Converter<F,T> converter)
Converts all the object in the iterable using the given Converter. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be converted
converter - The converter that specifies how each object in the iterable must be converted
Returns:
A list containing all the objects in the given iterable converted using the given Converter

extract

public static <F,T> java.util.List<T> extract(java.lang.Object iterable,
                                              T argument)
Converts all the object in the iterable extracting the property defined by the given argument. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be converted
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A list containing the argument's value extracted from the object in the given iterable

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be converted in strings
Returns:
A list containing the String representation of the objects in the given iterable

extractProperty

public static <F,T> java.util.List<T> extractProperty(java.lang.Object iterable,
                                                      java.lang.String propertyName)
Converts all the object in the iterable extracting the named property. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be converted
propertyName - The name of the item's property on which the item must have no duplicated value
Returns:
A list containing the property's value extracted from the object in the given iterable

map

public static <F,T> java.util.Map<T,F> map(java.lang.Object iterable,
                                           Converter<F,T> converter)
Maps the objects in the given iterable on the value extracted using the given Converter. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be mapped
converter - The converter that specifies the key on which each object should be mapped
Returns:
A map having as keys the argument value extracted from the objects in the given iterable and as values the corresponding objects

index

public static <F,T> java.util.Map<T,F> index(java.lang.Object iterable,
                                             T argument)
Indexes the objects in the given iterable on the value of their argument. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be indexed
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A map having as keys the argument value extracted from the objects in the given iterable and as values the corresponding objects
